title: Ariz. 42, Det. 17: Lions commit 6 TOs; Stafford benched
text:
Last Slide Next Slide 
Matthew Stafford stood at the 40-yard line, his hands clasped behind his back, a gray Lions baseball cap on his head, looking like the loneliest person in fast-emptying Ford Field. 
The Detroit Lions benched their Golden Boy quarterback , the No. 1 overall pick in the 2009 draft, early in the third quarter of Sunday’s 42-17 blowout loss to the Arizona Cardinals at Ford Field after he threw his third interception in a meltdown of epic proportions. 
The Lions committed six turnovers, gave up a 99-yard touchdown drive and, after falling to 0-5 in what’s shaping up to be a disaster of a year, are now faced with a looming quarterback controversy and no legitimate chance to salvage their season. 
Stafford, who had taken every Lions snap but two kneel-downs since the start of 2013 and had never been pulled in a game except for injury or competitive reasons in his seven-year career, threw his first interception on the game's opening series, another on the Lions' first possession of the second quarter and was pulled after Patrick Peterson picked off a fourth-and-3 pass intended for Calvin Johnson on the Lions' opening drive of the second half. 
He finished 20 of 32 passing for 188 yards, and had a brief, non-animated sideline exchange with offensive coordinator Joe Lombardi after his benching. 
After their talk, with both men looking forward so as not to draw too much attention, Stafford then stood alone near the 40-yard line while Dan Orlovsky warmed up on the sideline. 
Both Lombardi and Lions coach Jim Caldwell defended Stafford amid mounting criticism this week, with Lombardi saying, “I still don’t think he’s broken,” a reference to comments Lombardi made after being hired as coordinator in January of 2014. 
On Sunday, though, Stafford and just about everything else Lions was broken. 
Ameer Abdullah fumbled on his fourth carry of the game and was benched after nearly fumbling away a kickoff in the second quarter. The Cardinals (4-1) would have recovered the fumble, but Tony Jefferson touched the ball while his leg was out of bounds. 
The Lions scored their only touchdown of the game on their third possession, after two turnovers, then turned the ball over twice more before halftime. 
Stafford threw his second interception early in the second quarter, and one series after the Cardinals scoured on a 99-yard drive – John Brown beat Darius Slay for a 49-yard pass to get Arizona out of its own end zone, then Chris Johnson broke a 40-yard run two plays later – Golden Tate fumbled away a catch. 
Orlovsky, who had not thrown a pass since 2012, joined the turnover brigade, throwing an interception in the fourth quarter. 
Orlovsky completed 21 of 38 passes for 191 yards and led the Lions to two meaningless scores in the fourth quarter. The Lions' 70 pass attempts tied an NFL record. 
The Lions, who play their next two games at home against division opponents the Chicago Bears and Minnesota Vikings before heading to London to take on the Kansas City Chiefs, now have to figure out what to do with Stafford. 
Two years ago, Stafford signed a three-year extension with the Lions worth $41.7 million. 
The Lions can get out of the deal without owing Stafford, who turns 28 in February, any more money after this season. He still would count $11 million against the salary cap if the Lions decide to go in another direction. 
Johnson finished with 103 yards rushing on 11 carries and Carson Palmer completed 11 of 14 passes for 161 yards and three touchdowns for the Cardinals before giving way to Drew Stanton in the fourth quarter.
